III.    Facility Identification

The Watershed Foods facility is located at 202 North Ford Street in Gridley, Illinois.  The facility is a supplier of freeze-dried ingredients. The NAICS code for the facility is 311423. 



The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There are two (2) refrigeration systems onsite that are used for cold storage and freeze drying product. 



The amount of ammonia currently present in the Freezer refrigeration system is approximately 10,000 pounds.  The Freezer refrigeration system is used to cool the main freezer area, USDA Cooler, Slicing Room, Shipping and Receiving Dock, Yogurt Production Room, and Holding Room.  This system is a single stage system with three (3) low stage compressors.  Evaporators are fed with high pressure liquid from the receiver, through the recirculator.



The amount of ammonia currently present in the Dryer refrigeration system is approximately 7,000 pounds.  The Dryer refrigeration system is used to freeze dry fruit and yogurt.  It is a single stage system with two (2) low stage compressors.  Evaporators in the production areas are fed with high pressure liquid from the receiver, through the recirculator. 



The total amount of ammonia onsite, considering the quantities in the Freezer and Dryer ammonia refrigeration systems, is approximately 17,000 pounds, which is above the minimum threshold quantity of 10,000 pounds.

VI.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program

A prevention program is in place to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   However, as discussed throughout this document Watershed Foods is actively working on improving this program. 



This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The most recent audit of the PSM program was conducted on June 8 and 9, 2010, and the next audit will occur before June 8 and 9, 2013, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.

?    Employee Participation - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participation program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  

?    Process Safety Information - Watershed Foods maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. 

?    Process Hazard Analysis - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific PHA program that ensures a PHA is conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to

require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Watershed Foods conducted a thorough PHA study for the Freezer and Dryer ammonia refrigeration systems on November 17, 18, 30 and December 1, 2010.

?    Operating Procedures - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Watershed Foods updated operating procedures for both the Freezer and Dryer refrigeration systems during October and November 2010.  Annually, the operating procedures will be reviewed and certified as accurate.

?    Training - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.

?    Management of Change - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other procedures are documented. 

?    Pre-Startup Review - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific pre-startup safety review procedure that ensures a safety review is performed when modifications to the ammonia process are significant enough to require a change in PSI.

?    Mechanical Integrity - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific mechanical integrity procedure that ensures written preventative maintenance procedures are developed and maintained, preventative maintenance tests and inspections are properly documented, and employees maintaining the process receive adequate training.  Watershed Foods formalized maintenance procedures for the Freezer and Dryer refrigera

tion systems during October and November 2010.

?    Contractor Qualifications - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific contractor qualification procedure that ensures all contract employers' safety performance and programs are evaluated, a contract employee injury and illness log is maintained, information of potential hazards are communicated between Watershed Foods and the contract employer, and required training and information is communicated, such as the provisions of the emergency action plan and control over entrance into process areas.

?    Incident Investigation - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific incident investigation procedure that ensures each incident that either results in a release or could have resulted in a release of anhydrous ammonia is investigated, within 48 hours, by a team of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  This procedure will also make provisions to ensure a report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation and findings are promptly addressed. 

?    Compliance Audit - Watershed Foods has updated a site-specific compliance audit program that ensures compliance audits are conducted at a minimum of every three years to verify that Watershed Foods PSM/RMP practices and procedures are adequate and are being followed.  A compliance audit was conducted on June 8 and 9, 2010. The next compliance audit will be conducted by June 8 and 9, 2013.  

?    Hot Work Permits - Watershed Foods has updated a best management practice for hot work.  



VII.    Five-Year Accident History

The Watershed Foods facility has not had an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.





VIII.    Emergency Response Program

Watershed Foods has developed an emergency action plan to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel

are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 



Watershed Foods has communicated and trained facility employees on proper evacuation procedures and has had interaction with the McClean County Emergency Management Agency (EMA) Team. 



Watershed Foods has coordinated their emergency action plan with the McClean County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the McClean County EMA Team.  This coordination effort includes providing each aforementioned agency with a copy of our emergency action plan, providing each with a site diagram and hazardous material information.



Although Watershed Foods does not have an onsite hazardous materials response team, selected individuals have received HAZWOPER training through classroom instruction, on-the-job training, and drills.  The current HAZWOPER training includes the first responder awareness level, the first responder operations level, and hazardous materials technician training.  



The facility has two (2) windsocks present onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.



The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 





IX.    Emergency Communications

The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.





X.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Chemical safety is an important part of Watershed Foods operations. Watershed Foods recently conducted an audit of their Process Safety Management Program and will be dutifully implementing the recommendations from that audit. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Watershed Foods. 



XI.    Management Program

Watershed Foods has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in

the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, William Foree, Maintenance Engineering, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
